textClass.keywords: Benzo(a)pyrene Antioxidant enzyme Stress-related gene Coral bleaching

abstract.p: The impact of acute benzo(a)pyrene on antioxidant enzyme and stress-related genes in tropical stony corals (Acropora spp.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Coral reefs possess high biodiversity and productivity in tropical and subtropical waters. They evolved over two hundred million years, and provide space for spawning, breeding and sheltering for fish, algae and invertebrates. Furthermore, they offer physical protection enabling the formation and persistence of associated tropical ecosystems such as seagrass meadows and mangrove forests (Hoegh-Guldberg, 1999). In recent decades, coral reefs have repeatedly suffered from serious bleaching around the world. Apart from abnormal temperatures, radiation and ocean acidification, chemical pollutants are reported to pose a serious threat to the persistence of coral reefs (Gleason and Wellington, 1994;Hoegh-Guldberg, 1999;Cervino et al., 2004;Lawrence et al., 2015).

Polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) are a group of common pollutants in the marine environment and are composed of two or more fused conjugated benzene rings, which are mainly derived from oil leakage and combustion of petroleum and biomass (Dam et al., 2011;Tongo et al., 2017). PAHs can easily be enriched in corals from ambient compartments because of their particular characteristics of hydrophobicity and lipophilicity (Hawliczek et al., 2012). Based on previous studies, the PAHs concentrations detected in corals were relatively higher than in ambient sediments, indicating bioaccumulation of PAHs in corals (Ko et al., 2014;Xiang et al., 2018). Benzo(a)pyrene (BaP) is a five-ring PAH, and it is a model PAH widely studied in ecotoxicology, and has attracted special concern due to its teratogenic, carcinogenic and mutational toxicity (Williams and Hubberstey, 2014). Extensive studies have demonstrated that BaP can be toxic to marine organisms including corals, mussels and oysters (Ramos and García, 2007;Chen et al., 2016;Jiang et al., 2016). Their survival rates gradually decrease with increasing anthracene concentrations of up to 378 μg•L −1 . The presence of anthracene and ultraviolet (uv) radiation had a substantial effect on larval survival (Overmans et al., 2018). It has also been reported that the concentrations of BaP in corals ranged from 1.13 ng•g −1 to 42.50 ng•g −1 in Hainan Island (Xiang et al., 2018), but data regarding the toxic effects of BaP on corals are rare.

Reactive oxygen species (ROS) are normally maintained at low levels, and the generation of ROS is generally regarded as a stress response in organisms exposed to exogenous pollutants. Furthermore, high concentrations of ROS can cause oxidative damage to DNA, proteins and cell membranes. The antioxidant enzyme system usually plays an important role in removing excess free radicals when coral is exposed to chemical pollutants (Edge et al., 2005). Superoxide dismutase (SOD) is regarded as the most important enzyme which reduces damage resulting from radicals (Birben et al., 2012). There is evidence from the stony coral, Montastraea faveolata, that SOD is a part of the overall response to BaP exposure (Ramos and García, 2007).

Molecular tools, such as the real-time quantitative polymerase chain reaction (RT-qPCR) have been applied to investigate the underlying mechanisms of the response of organisms to toxicant exposure (Downs et al., 2000;Morgan et al., 2001;Morgan and Snell, 2002;Bard, 2008). Heat shock proteins (HSPs), especially Hsp70, are an important family of genes, which function as a defence against external disturbances in organisms. They have been widely regarded as early biomarkers of the response to coral bleaching (Lindquist and Craig, 1988;Desalvo et al., 2008). The ATP-binding cassette (ABC) protein family is known for its role in cellular defence. The P-gp gene belongs to the ABC family and has been described as a first instance of defence against toxins (Epel, 1998). In addition, the P-gp gene is regularly induced in aquatic organisms when exposure to natural toxins or anthropogenic contaminants occurs, and induces the removal of hazardous substances (Bard, 2000).

However, information concerning the stress responsive genes in corals, particularly under exposure to chemical pollutants, is very limited. The combination of antioxidant enzymes and gene expression can effectively evaluate the toxic effects of pollutants on organisms (Qian et al., 2008). The average concentrations of PAHs in corals are increasing globally, from 0.3 ng/g in the Kuwait Gulf (Readman et al., 1996) and 58 ng/g in Puerto Rico (Pait et al., 2009) to 500-1000 ng/g in the Gulf of Mexico, and in Kenting and Sanya Bays (Pait et al., 2009;Ko et al., 2014;Xiang et al., 2018). It is important to analyse the response of corals to BaP exposure and to compare different response mechanisms between species. In this study, we quantified the oxidative stress and stress-related gene expressions for two Acropora species, A. formosa and A. nasuta, exposed to BaP. Our major objectives are: (1) to examine the acute effects of BaP on Acropora spp. at multiple biological levels;
(2) to compare the different responses and sensitivity between A. formosa and A. nasuta and (3) to find biomarkers for coral stress following PAHs pollution.

div.head: Experimental animals and BaP exposure
div.p: A. formosa and A. nasuta were collected from Hainan Island, China in March of 2017. The corals were immediately transported to the laboratory and were then left to recover in a 1.4 m 3 aquarium containing filtered seawater (temperature, 28 ± 0.5°C; pH, 8.0 ± 0.1; salinity, 34‰). After acclimation for five days, small coral fragments (5 cm diameter) were prepared using a hammer and chisel, and placed into a large aquarium for seven days to recover. No mortality was observed for any of the corals.

Benzo[a]pyrene (BaP) was purchased from Sigma (St. Louis Missouri, USA) and dissolved in dimethylsulfoxide (DMSO) and the final concentration of DMSO was b0.0001% of the tank volume. During the experiments, DMSO was used for the control group along with filtered seawater to eliminate its toxic effects on corals. Thus, in total, the experimental design consisted of treatments with 10 and 40 μg•L −1 BaP, a DMSO control, and a seawater control. A total of 25 coral fragments were maintained in each tank with 12 h of light and 12 h of darkness with seawater renewal every 24 h. The seawater parameters (e.g., temperature, pH, and salinity) were in accordance with the acclimation period and each sample consisted of three replicates.

div.head: Sample collection and preparation
div.p: Coral samples were collected randomly from each replicate with a stainless steel clamp after 24 hand 72 h of exposure to BaP and were immediately frozen in liquid nitrogen, and then stored at −80°C until analysis.

div.head: Seawater analysis
div.p: To confirm variations in BaP concentrations over 24 h, 2 L seawater samples were collected from the tanks immediately after the initial addition of BaP and after 24 h exposure, but prior to renewal of the seawater. The detailed procedures of treatment and extraction were performed according to Li et al. (2015). 10 mL dichloromethane (HPLC grade, merck, Germany), 10 mL methanol (HPLC grade, Merck, Germany) and 10 mL ultrapure water were used to activate the SPE Solution Classic C18 cartridge in sequence. A total of 5 mL methanol (HPLC grade) was added to 500 mL of the water samples. The samples were blended and then pre-concentrated by the SPE method at a flow rate of 5 mL•min −1 , then 12 mL of dichloromethane (HPLC grade) was used to elute the BaP three times. Next, the eluents were removed by anhydrous sodium sulfate and concentrated using a gentle stream of dry nitrogen in a 45°C water bath. Finally, the residue was dissolved in 1 mL methanol (HPLC grade) for the GC-MS (Agilent, Palo Alto, CA, USA) analysis.

The target objects were separated by an HP-5 fused silica capillary column (30 m × 0.25 mm × 0.25 μm, Agilent). The programmed temperatures of the oven were as follows: maintain an initial temperature at 100°C for 2 min; then increase to 200°C at a rate of 10°C•min −1 , next, increase to 300°C at a rate of 5°C•min −1 , and finally an isothermal pause for 5 min at 300°C. The carrier gas was helium with a flow rate of 1.0 mL•min −1 . A total of 1 μL of extracted sample was injected into a splitless injector with a 1 min solvent delay each time. The correlation coefficient of the calibration curve was N0.999, the recovery of BaP ranged from 90.5% to 109.7%, the relative standard deviations (RSD) were 6% to 22% and the limits of detection (LOD) were in good agreement with the certified values and varied from 0.12 to 1.07 ng•L −1 .

div.head: Chlorophyll a content
div.p: Coral samples (n = 5) were washed gently with 0.22 μm-filtered seawater (FSW) to eliminate weeds. Each coral fragment (approximately 3-5 cm) was extracted over 24 h at 4°C in 100% acetone. The extracts were then centrifuged at 4500 rpm for 10 min, and the absorbance was measured at 630, 647 and 664 nm. The concentration of chlorophyll a (Chl a) was analysed according to Jeffrey and Humphrey (1975) (chl a = 11.85 E 664 -1.54 E 647 -0.08 E 630 ) and was expressed as micrograms (μg) of chl a per cm −2 of corals. The surface areas of the corals were determined using the foil method (Venn et al., 2009). The weight of 1 m 2 foil was measured first and the surface areas of foils around the corals were obtained by their weights.

div.head: Biochemical analysis
div.p: Coral tissues and zooxanthellae were removed with a Waterpik dental water jet by 75-100 mL of 0.45 μm FSW (Fitt et al., 2000). Triplicates were centrifuged for 10 min at 5500 rpm after a short period of blending. After discarding the supernatants, normal saline (0.9% sodium chloride solution) was added and then homogenized in an ice bath by an Ultrasonic Cell Disruption System (Sonics). Finally, the homogenate was centrifuged at 2500 rpm for 10 min at 4°C and the diluent supernatant (1% homogenize) was used for next analysis.

Measurements of total protein concentrations and superoxide dismutase (SOD) activity were performed according to the instructions in the assay kits from the Nanjing Jiancheng Bioengineering Institute (Nanjing, China) (Zhang et al., 2019). The absorbance was measured by a Lambda 25 ultraviolet spectrophotometer (PerkinElmer, USA) at 550 nm (McCord and Day, 1978). One unit of SOD activity was defined as the amount of enzyme required to cause 50% inhibition of cytochrome c reduction. Protein concentrations were expressed as g•L −1 and the SOD activity was reported as U•mg −1 protein.

div.head: RNA extraction and cDNA synthesis
div.p: Total RNA was extracted according to the method of Trizol (Invitrogen). Corals were immediately ground in liquid nitrogen and mg coral powder was transferred into 2 mL centrifuge tubes, then resuspended in 1 mL ice-cold Trizol reagent. The specific experimental methods were consistent with the manufacturer instructions. After confirming the total RNA concentration with a Nanodrop 2000 spectrophotometer (Thermo, Germany) and purity by a Gel imaging system (Bio-Rad, The United States), 2 μg mRNA was purified from the total RNA samples by poly-dT oligo, and then fragmented at 72°C for 5 min. The second-strand cDNA was synthesized following the GoScript reverse transcription system (Promega, Madison, WI, USA).

div.head: Quantitative RT-PCR (qRT-PCR) analysis
div.p: The qRT-PCR analysis was performed using a ROCHE Light Cycler 96 Real-Time Cycler PCR Detection System (Roche Applied Science, Mannheim, Germany) by SYBR green Master I (Roche, USA). The following primers are used for target genes. Forward/Reverse sequence for Hsp70 (5′-3′) (GCCTTACGCCGCCTGAA; CTGGACGACAGGGTTCTCTTG), P-gp (GGCGATAACTCGCGTGAAGT; TGTGTATATTTGCGGCTTTTGC), β-actin (GTTCCACCATGTACCCAGGAA; GGAGCCAGGAGCAGTGATTTC) (Venn et al., 2009).

The reaction was carried out with the FastStart Essential DNA Green Master (Roche) system containing cDNA, ddH 2 O and primers. Thermal cycling conditions were 95°C for 10 min of preincubation, followed by 45 cycles of amplification at 95°C for 15 s and 60°C for 90 s, then three-step melting followed by cooling at 37°C for 30 s. All samples were examined in triplicate on the same plate (n = 3). The β-actin gene was used for positive control and the delta-delta Ct (2 −ΔΔCt ) method was applied to quantity the relative expression levels of genes (Livak and Schmittgen, 2001), which were expressed as n-fold increases compared to the control. A melting curve at the end of the PCR was used to test the specificity of all primers.

div.head: Statistical analysis
div.p: Statistical analyses were performed using GraphPad Prism 5 and SPSS 17.0. The significant differences in variables between treatments were analysed by one-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) with Duncan's test. An effect of p b 0.05 was considered to be significant, whereas p b 0.01 was regarded as highly significant.

div.head: BaP concentration variations
div.p: As displayed in Table 1, at 0 h of exposure, the corals were not in the tanks, so the loss of BaP may have been due to BaP binding to the tank walls. After an exposure time of 24 h, a reduction in BaP was observed in A. formosa and A. nasuta of the treatment groups. The loss of BaP can be attributed here to its attachment to tank walls and to absorption by corals and photolysis. No BaP was detected in the control groups.

div.head: Chlorophyll a content
div.p: Lower total Chl a concentrations (p b 0.05) were observed in Acropora spp. after 72 h of BaP exposure although the colonies showed no obvious signs of bleaching (Fig. 1). The hypothesis of cellular mechanism holds that corals bleach when the Chl a concentrations of zooxanthellae reach low levels (Kuguru et al., 2010). We speculate that extended exposure to Bap can potentially cause coral bleaching.

A more significant decrease in Chl a content was found in A. formosa than in A. nasuta under BaP exposure for 72 h. This result possibly suggests that the zooxanthellae in A. nasuta are more prepared or tolerant to BaP stress, which could also explain why the SOD activity was found to be higher at 24 h in A. nasuta while being exposed to 10 μg•L −1 BaP (Fig. 2). We also speculate that the impacts on health caused by BaP induced stress are more serious in A. formosa than in A. nasuta.

The concentrations of Chl a are widely used to assess the health conditions of reef corals (Venn et al., 2009;Hédouin et al., 2016). Heavy metals such as copper (Cu) and lead (Pb) can directly influence the concentrations of Chl a in scleractinian coral, Pocillopora damicornis (Hédouin et al., 2016).

Additionally, the hypothesis of photoinhibitory damage refers to the mechanism for albinism caused by the obstruction of electron transfer in the photosynthetic system of zooxanthellae and the accumulation (Lesser, 1996). Increased Chl a concentrations in zooxanthellae promote the production of active oxygen species for defence against pathogens. Zooxanthellae loss is regarded as a bioassay to assess stress in corals and reduced Chl a content is an important biochemical parameter of this process (Jones, 1997). In another study (Crawley et al., 2010), Acropora Formosa displayed its Chl a sensitivity in zooxanthellae by dynamic symbiont photorespiration and productivity under ocean acidification condition.

div.head: SOD activity
div.p: As shown in Fig. 2, after 24 h BaP exposure (10 μg•L −1 and 40 μg•L −1 ), the SOD activity was significantly inhibited (p b 0.01) in A. formosa. The observed decrease in SOD activity after 24 h of BaP exposure in A. formosa may be attributed to its natural antioxidant defence (Ma et al., 2012). In contrast, the SOD activity in A. formosa increased significantly (p b 0.01) when it was exposed to 10 μg•L −1 BaP for 72 h. Additionally, the SOD activities increased in both Acropora spp. after 72 h of BaP exposure, and in A. formosa under 24 h of BaP pressure. The SOD activities induced in scleractinian corals are known to eliminate reactive free radicals as a protective response (Ramos and García, 2007).

In A. nasuta, the SOD activities were significantly induced with a 10 μg•L −1 dose at 24 h (p b 0.01) and with a 40 μg•L −1 dose at 72 h (p b 0.01). Noticeably, there were increased SOD activities in both A. formosa and A. nasuta after 72 h of BaP exposure, indicating their stress responses. Given the clear oxidative stress response, it is obvious that BaP exposure can increase the production of ROS in corals as shown by the activated SOD activity. Furthermore, a study performed by Higuchi et al. (2015) revealed that increased production of ROS in coral symbionts was regarded as an initial response to coral bleaching due to oxidative stress.

The antioxidant defence mechanisms mainly allow metabolization, detoxification, and antioxidant protection to help corals survive under anthropogenic changes (Kaur and Kaur, 2015). Acropora spp. showed a strong biochemical response to 10 μg•L −1 BaP exposure for 24 h and h, indicating that it may not have had enough time to activate the antioxidant defence system under 40 μg•L −1 BaP exposure with more serious damage. This was also consistent with observations by (Pan et al., 2009), the SOD activities of the scallop, Chlamys farreri, gland increased for 0.5 μg•L −1 and 1.0 μg•L −1 BaP groups. However, SOD activities showed a rapid increase and then dropped to or below the control level in the 10 μg•L −1 and 50 μg•L −1 groups.

It is noteworthy that O 2 − cannot diffuse readily through membranes and is dealt with by SOD. H 2 O 2 does diffuse easily and rapidly across a membrane layer, and is detoxified by catalase in the coral Favia favus (Levy et al., 2006). The high SOD activities seen in our study are probably a response of corals to acute BaP exposure. Algal-generated H 2 O 2 in a coral holobiont can diffuse from the algal symbiont into the coral cytoplasm. Once H 2 O 2 is inside the coral cytosol, it can be converted into the hydroxyl radical, which then eventually leads to coral bleaching unless it is neutralized by protective enzymes (Downs et al., 2002).

div.head: Gene expression
div.p: Hsp70 and P-gp gene expressions were significantly altered by BaP in Acropora spp. (p b 0.01) (Fig. 3). Compared to the control group, no significant differences in Hsp70 gene expressions were detected in A. formosa under BaP exposure for 24 h and in A. nasuta under 24 h and 72 h BaP exposure (p N 0.05). After 72 h exposure, the Hsp70 gene expressions in A. formosa were significantly inhibited (p b 0.01) in the 10 and 40 μg•L −1 BaP groups with obvious dose effects. Analysing gene expression was considered to be a useful approach in interpreting the coral stress response (Edge et al., 2005). Hsp70 is associated with cell defence for maintaining the integrity of cellular structures, interacting with unfolding proteins and regulating the immune system (Welch, 1992;Pandey et al., 2014).

Similar to our results, Nakamura et al. (2012) reported that a significant decrease in the expression of Hsp70 was observed in the larvae of Acropora digitifera under ocean acidification conditions at 27°C for 7 days. We observed reduced Hsp70 transcript abundance, indicating that A. formosa's defensive gene expression responds very sensitively to BaP pollution, but this sensitivity to BaP was not observed in A. nasuta.

The P-gp gene was significantly expressed in A. formosa following a 24 h exposure to BaP (Fig. 3). Toxicants were removed from the cells through energy-dependent processes by ABC proteins (Dean et al., 2001;Venn et al., 2009). This increased P-gp expression could be attributed to its role as an efflux pump responding to chemical pollutants (Higgins, 1992;Bard, 2000). A similar result was found in A. nasuta after BaP exposure for longer times and at higher concentrations (40 μg•L −1 BaP for 72 h) (Fig. 3). It also indicates that the P-gp gene was more sensitive in A. formosa than in A. nasuta. The presence of BaP may result in an increase in the cellular multi-drug/multi-xenobiotic defensive activity of Acropora spp. cells by upregulated expression levels of P-gp. We speculate that P-gp transports toxic substances or their metabolic products in corals under BaP exposure.

The increased expression of P-gp was also found in the reef coral, Montastraea franksi, when exposed to an oil dispersant Corexit™9527 and to the heavy metal copper (Venn et al., 2009). Moreover, induction of the P-gp expression was regarded as a common stress in response to abnormal temperature and salinity in the marine mussel, Mytilus edulis (Luedeking and Koehler, 2004). It is worth mentioning that the P-gp expression significantly changed for shorter times of BaP exposure than for Hsp70, indicating that it could be a more sensitive marker of the toxic effects of BaP stress than Hsp 70. This result is contrary to a previous study indicating that Hsp70 is a more sensitive biomarker of oildispersant stress than P-gp in corals (Venn et al., 2009).

Different responses of the stress-related genes in A. formosa and A. nasuta to BaP exposure may demonstrate their specificity to species for antioxidant defence. The cellular and molecular defensive mechanisms of corals in response to environmental pressures are extremely important because they are constantly exposed to increasing levels of anthropogenic contaminants in their habitats (Jeong et al., 2017).

div.head: Conclusions
div.p: Based on the current study, BaP exposure of 24 h did not cause observed negative effects on zooxanthellae pigments but significantly damaged the health of corals, according to the impairment of antioxidant enzyme activities and stress-related gene expressions in Acropora spp. Exposure to BaP can cause more toxic effects for A. formosa than for A. nasuta, especially when the exposure time was 72 h, and enzymes and gene expression displayed their defensive responses to ROS. The SOD activities and P-gp gene expressions were induced, whereas the Hsp70 gene expressions were inhibited. Our results provide a better comprehensive reference for physiological and molecular toxicological studies with Acropora spp. and with scleractinian corals. This study also provides a basis for future biomarker studies in corals exposed to organic contaminants.

figure.head: Fig. 1 .
figure.figDesc: Chlorophyll a content (total concentration -μg chl per cm −2 -and per cell -μg chl per cell -, n = 5) in A. formosa (A) and A. nasuta (B) exposed to BaP. Different letters indicate significant differences at a level of 0.05.

figure.head: Fig. 2 .
figure.figDesc: The effects of BaP on SOD activities in A. formosa (A) and A. nasuta (B). Different letters indicate significant differences at a level of 0.05.

figure.head: Fig. 3 .
figure.figDesc: The effects of BaP on the expression levels of stress-related genes (a) Hsp70, (b) P-gp in A. formosa (A) and A. nasuta (B). Different letters indicate significant differences at a level of 0.05.

figure.head: Table 1
figure.figDesc: Mean seawater concentrations of BaP (n = 3) during 24 h exposure periods.

body.note: N. Xiang et al. / Science of the Total Environment 694 (2019) 133474

div.head: Acknowledgements
div.p: This project was supported by the National Science Foundation of China (31560165 and 31760164) and the China Scholarship Council (Scholarship No. 201707565023). The authors would like to express their appreciation to Dr. Lei Jiang of the South China Sea Institute of Oceanology at the Chinese Academy of Sciences for his assistance in the identification of coral species. We sincerely thank the editors and the anonymous reviewers for their valuable comments and suggestions on this paper.
